articles.title: Ancient people carried a wild potato across the American Southwest
articles.summary: Long before farming took hold, ancient Indigenous peoples of the American Southwest were already shaping the future of a wild potato. New evidence shows that this small, hardy plant was deliberately carried across the Four Corners region more than 10,000 years ago, helping it spread far beyond its natural range.
articles.content:
More than 10,000 years ago, people living in the southwestern United States carried a wild ancestor of the modern potato across long distances. According to a study published January 21, 2026 in the open-access journal PLOS One, this movement likely helped the plant spread beyond its original habitat. The research was led by Lisbeth Louderback of the University of Utah, U.S., along with her colleagues.

The findings suggest that Indigenous communities played an active role in shaping the plant's future. By moving and using this wild potato, they may have begun the earliest stages of domestication while also building a distinctive cultural tradition in the Four Corners region.

The Four Corners Potato and Its Ancient Use

The plant at the center of the study is known as the Four Corners potato (Solanum jamesii). It is a small but hardy and nutritious wild potato that still grows across southwestern North America today, ranging from southern Utah and Colorado into northern Mexico.

To learn how the potato was used in the past, researchers examined ground stone tools from 14 archaeological sites. These sites span a wide stretch of time, from several hundred to many thousands of years old. The tools were tested for tiny starch granules left behind when plants were processed for food.

Stone Tools and Genetic Clues Tell the Story

Starch from the Four Corners potato was identified on tools from nine of the sites. Some of the evidence dates back as far as 10,900 cal BP. Most of these locations sit near the modern northern edge of the potato's range, along the borders of Colorado, Utah, Arizona, and New Mexico.

Earlier genetic research adds another layer of evidence. Some living populations of the Four Corners potato in this northern area show strong genetic signs that they originated much farther south. This supports the idea that people carried the plant across the region, extending its range north into Utah and Colorado, where it still grows today.

Early Domestication and Living Cultural Traditions

Researchers note that repeated use of a plant and its movement beyond its natural range are both key indicators of early domestication. In this case, those behaviors appear to have begun thousands of years ago.

Even today, the Four Corners potato holds cultural importance for Indigenous communities. Alongside laboratory work, the research team interviewed 15 Navajo (Diné) elders. These conversations confirmed that the wild potato remains known, eaten, and used for spiritual purposes.

Lisbeth Louderback adds: "By combining new archaeobotanical data and elder interviews with transport patterns identified by genetic sequencing of the Four Corners potato, we have defined an anthropogenic range distinct from its natural distribution. This reveals a unique cultural identity developed by ancient transport of this species -- one that continues into the present day."

Cynthia Wilson adds: "The mobility of Indigenous foodways was driven by kinship-based practices across the landscape. Indigenous knowledge holders, especially matrilineal women, held on to these seedlings and stories across generations to sustain ties to ancestral land and foodways."

Funding: This work was funded by the National Science Foundation (Award BCS-1827414). General funding was also received from Red Butte Garden and the Natural History Museum of Utah.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant archaeological and cultural discovery showing how ancient Indigenous peoples actively shaped the distribution and early domestication of a wild potato over 10,000 years ago. This has broad significance for understanding human-plant relationships, Indigenous heritage, and cultural continuity in the American Southwest. The story is well-supported by scientific evidence and interviews, highlighting a meaningful positive impact on cultural knowledge and respect for Indigenous traditions.
articles.personality_title: Ancient peoples carried wild potato across the American Southwest 10,000 years ago
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Over 10,000 years ago, Indigenous peoples lived in the American Southwest where a wild potato called the Four Corners potato grew naturally. This hardy plant still grows today across parts of Utah, Colorado, Arizona, and New Mexico.

**What happened** – Researchers studied ancient stone tools from 14 sites in the region and found tiny pieces of starch from the Four Corners potato. Some starch traces were as old as 10,900 years. Genetic studies also showed that potato plants in northern areas originally came from farther south, meaning people carried the plant long distances.

**Impact** – This discovery shows that ancient Indigenous communities actively moved and used the wild potato, possibly starting its early domestication. It reveals how people shaped the plant’s spread and built cultural traditions around it. Today, the wild potato remains important to Indigenous groups, including the Navajo, who use it for food and spiritual purposes.

**What's next step** – Scientists will likely continue studying ancient plants and tools to learn more about early farming and Indigenous knowledge. This research also supports respecting and preserving Indigenous cultural traditions tied to plants like the Four Corners potato.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Ancient Indigenous peoples carried and used a wild potato across the Southwest more than 10,000 years ago, shaping its spread and cultural importance that continues today.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les peuples anciens transportaient une pomme de terre sauvage dans le sud-ouest américain il y a plus de 10 000 ans
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Il y a plus de 10 000 ans, des peuples autochtones vivaient dans le sud-ouest américain où poussait naturellement une pomme de terre sauvage appelée pomme de terre des Quatre Coins. Cette plante robuste pousse encore aujourd’hui dans certaines parties de l’Utah, du Colorado, de l’Arizona et du Nouveau-Mexique.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des chercheurs ont étudié des outils en pierre anciens provenant de 14 sites de la région et ont trouvé de minuscules traces d’amidon de la pomme de terre des Quatre Coins. Certaines traces datent d’il y a 10 900 ans. Des études génétiques ont aussi montré que les plants dans le nord venaient à l’origine du sud, ce qui signifie que les gens transportaient la plante sur de longues distances.

**Impact** – Cette découverte montre que les communautés autochtones anciennes déplaçaient et utilisaient activement cette pomme de terre sauvage, initiant peut-être sa domestication. Elle révèle comment les humains ont influencé la diffusion de la plante et créé des traditions culturelles autour d’elle. Aujourd’hui, cette pomme de terre reste importante pour les groupes autochtones, notamment les Navajos, qui l’utilisent pour l’alimentation et les rituels spirituels.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques continueront probablement à étudier les plantes anciennes et les outils pour mieux comprendre les débuts de l’agriculture et le savoir autochtone. Cette recherche aide aussi à respecter et préserver les traditions culturelles liées à des plantes comme la pomme de terre des Quatre Coins.

**Phrase clé** – Il y a plus de 10 000 ans, les peuples autochtones transportaient et utilisaient une pomme de terre sauvage dans le sud-ouest américain, façonnant sa diffusion et son importance culturelle encore vivante aujourd’hui.
articles.personality_title_es: Los pueblos antiguos transportaron una papa silvestre por el suroeste americano hace más de 10,000 años
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Hace más de 10,000 años, pueblos indígenas vivían en el suroeste de Estados Unidos donde crecía de forma natural una papa silvestre llamada papa de Cuatro Esquinas. Esta planta resistente aún crece hoy en partes de Utah, Colorado, Arizona y Nuevo México.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores estudiaron herramientas de piedra antiguas de 14 sitios en la región y encontraron pequeñas partículas de almidón de la papa de Cuatro Esquinas. Algunas pruebas tienen hasta 10,900 años. Estudios genéticos también mostraron que las plantas en el norte venían originalmente del sur, lo que indica que las personas transportaron la planta grandes distancias.

**Impacto** – Este descubrimiento muestra que las comunidades indígenas antiguas movían y usaban activamente esta papa silvestre, posiblemente comenzando su domesticación. Revela cómo las personas influenciaron la expansión de la planta y crearon tradiciones culturales alrededor de ella. Hoy, la papa sigue siendo importante para grupos indígenas, como los navajos, que la usan para comer y en ceremonias espirituales.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos probablemente seguirán estudiando plantas y herramientas antiguas para entender mejor los primeros cultivos y el conocimiento indígena. Esta investigación también apoya el respeto y la preservación de las tradiciones culturales relacionadas con plantas como la papa de Cuatro Esquinas.

**Frase clave** – Hace más de 10,000 años, pueblos indígenas transportaron y usaron una papa silvestre en el suroeste americano, moldeando su expansión y su importancia cultural que continúa hoy.
